snippet: The popularity of the drinks reflects success in convincing consumers that they provide an edge, but most of their ingredients have no or little benefit, research shows.
abstract: Energy drinks, fastest-growing part of beverage industry, claim to offer mental and physical edge, but review of scientific studies show that drinks are based on brew of ingredients that, apart from caffeine, have little benefit for consumers; rising popularity reflects industry's successful marketing campaign to convince Americans that drinks are specially engineered nutritional blends.

byline.contributor: Hiroko Tabuchi contributed reporting from Tokyo and Poypiti Amatatham from Bangkok.

lead_paragraph: The popularity of the drinks reflects success in convincing consumers that they provide an edge, but most of their ingredients have no or little benefit, research shows.

headline.seo: Scant Proof Is Found to Back Up Claims by Energy Drinks
headline.main: Energy Drinks Promise Edge, but Experts Say Proof Is Scant
headline.print_headline: Energy Drinks Promise Edge, But Experts Say Proof Is Scant
